JeKJ91REJIt2rZGn7UbyhA.text: Love this place with the secretive entrance. It's one of those rare places on orchard road that's not too crowded. They have a selection of finger food and small portions of ramen and rice. I had the karaage rice and the uma uma ramen. Both were pretty good. The drinks are little pricey. I had the zombie cocktail and it was pretty good. The bartender is nice and if you could name a drink, he could make it for you.

AfRWqP-7gO02--NeSenQbg.text: The good:  Louis, Louis, Louis.  I didn't want to like you, especially after hearing so many glowing reviews about you and your drinks.  I told myself that your drinks couldn't be that good, that you can't be that nice, I dismissed it all for biased hype (which it usually is).  Several days later, I'm fantasizing about my next visit as if I just had a fling with Victoria Secret model.  I lost myself for a bit there...      The bad:  Based strictly on drinks, I have nothing bad to say.  Louis nailed it every time, introducing me to familiar libations with a twist.  Each cocktail came with a story about the spirits used and how he's looking to improve the drinks even further.  A true bartender, in every sense of the word (I think there are like  5 senses, or something like that).  Consistently accessible, never lurking, completely professional and welcoming.  I ordered off the menu, only hinting a preference here and there.  Dude read my mind...and my soul.  Ok, this review is getting to be a bit too much, let's just cut to the ugly.     The ugly:  This place is cool...for now.  Has a few hidden doors that make for a surprise entrance or ninja bomb exit.  Next door is a high end Japanese restaurant that brings all the yaya papaya Japanese clients to the yard.  Above is a ramen spot that will, without a doubt, satisfy a bits and nibbles appetite.  Music was loungy, like my grandfather would have said turn it up loungy (my friend made several comments about falling asleep because of it, although it could have been my stories).  Because of the close restaurant link, location and decor, I don't see it ever being a "hot" spot.  It would be pretty sub-par if you had to stand or wait to order, but should you go when there is space at the bar I think you'll enjoy your cocktail adventure as much as I did.  It's a scary thought though when 1 bartender makes up the majority of the experience, so lets just hope the Horse's Mouth can keep Louis around for awhile.  If not, I'll follow the pied bartender wherever he may go.

BdHKYQntxsPAWV7nkFc5uA.text: not so much for the food but the super good cocktails @ bar downstairs. love the concoctions

TUr51L6hxkkkjHyJOps9Ow.text: Quirky decor (I really like the cut wood rough hewn to look like old books) and I like the quiet ambiance. I'm not exactly young so a place I can go have impeccable cocktails and TALK is very good. Also really liked it was not too crowded.The cocktails were perfectly prepared. I wish the food selections were a wee more eclectic, but on the whole, a great bar.

NRoS98mfTm_LzAs4pzCrmg.text: One of the better mixologist bars I've been to. I've been here twice, and it's been outstanding every time.I couldn't describe what I had, because every drink is slightly different, but the Sophie/Sophia is really amazing. Please order that, and make a booking if you come here on a Friday night.And don't get a shock when you get the bill. I think it's 25++ per drink. Worth every damned penny.

EH_ueJzKA4B5fzY_APL4wg.text: Nice hidden place, with really friendly and knowledgeable bartenders. Drinks are made with care - you can usually go bespoke and they'll make you whatever you like. Interior is a little dated though, and prices a little expensive for what you get. Quite a cool casual place, good space for a chill night of conversations.

5rVznlYllYbfLsgvnRdvRw.text: A very chic, well-decorated spot but be ready to spend some money.  Drinks here are expensive - cocktails are marked as $25++ (so confusing - how much more do those +'s signify?).  The drinks are well made, and the service was great.  I went on a Monday night at 8pm so it was very quiet, about 5 other people there besides my party.  We arrived earlier than some of our party, so we took time to look around at the wonderful interior design/decorations.  There are 3 glass cases that have paper flowers with mirrors illuminating the lights and colors of the flowers.  So beautiful!  As for the food, we munched on some cheese balls and ice cream sandwiches.  Do yourself a favor and skip the ice cream sandwiches - they were bland and unfulfilling.  The cheese balls warrant a try.  They were cheesy and not too heavy.  Overall, I would come here again when I'm visiting but it wouldn't be on the top of my to-do list.

Yn-ZndAdyej-CRvcNioe1A.text: You definitely pay for the ambiance here, but it's worth it once in a while. Secret entrance is a bonus. Cocktails have a Japanese twist, but will cost you 25++. The Sloe 'n Steady was my kind of drink, citrusy and refreshing without tasting too much of alcohol. Mockup on whiskey is about 2x, and there are only a few wines that are sold by the glass.

xNVgrxa-xS8kva0Rzgvnqw.text: Purely rating based on Food.  I say this would be a good place for your snack.  But if you are looking to really fill up your belly with them snacks errrrr.....that would not be a good idea.  Ambience and service all good.  And yes indeed a little on the pricey side.  So really drinks and snacks don't do what we did trying to fullfill our dinner with snacks :).

photos.caption: Photo of Horse's Mouth - Singapore, Singapore. Interior
Photo of Horse's Mouth - Singapore, Singapore. Zen
Photo of Horse's Mouth - Singapore, Singapore. Decor

5ZdeVbtUKaBbHyL4SZWDsw.text: The place is located in a hidden place where one can enter through Uma Uma Ramen which is located above it. The place is dimly lighted, so it is quite difficult to take a good picture here. Although there is not much customers, I am showed to a counter seat. The counter is packed with 2 loud groups, while the tables only has a quiet couple at one end. Bushi Tonkotsu Ramen ($19++)Bonito flakes, chasiu, white onions, bamboo shoots, egg, lime & red gingerI am told that the lime is used to kill off the strong fishy taste, although it does not make much of a different in the soup. The lime is given in a slice instead of a wedge, so it is quite difficult to squeeze out any juice. As the aircon is quite strong the dish turns cold very fast. The dish tastes quite average.Bespoke Cocktail ($25)It is a mixture of Diplomatico Añejo rum, pineapple juice, passion fruit and almond. Tastes not bad, except that I have gone through a terrible experience with the staffs when ordering the drink. I have thought that I have ordered but it never comes. The billing of the drink is not what I expected.Overall poor service from the staffs. Food is average.

photos.caption: Photo of Horse's Mouth - Singapore, Singapore. Bushi Tonkotsu Ramen
Photo of Horse's Mouth - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Horse's Mouth - Singapore, Singapore. Bespoke Cocktail

GtWGWwZPXQhTQtAw8dMqIA.text: After so many missed opportunities, I finally made it out to Horse's Mouth! This is a fun bar to enter, at least if you do it through Uma Uma Ramen. Walk in, wave at the staff and say you're going downstairs, press the button that's slightly hidden on the side of the wall, watch as the black door just swooshes open, and descend to the basement where all the liquor is!In the past, walking in on a Friday night was impossible as they'd be fully booked, so I made sure to make a reservation this time. But surprisingly it was very quiet this time around. Was it because it was Deepavali earlier in the week and everyone went on holiday? Or could it be because Louis, the bartender everyone talks about, moved to L'Aiglon on Neil Road? Or are locals over the trend of speakeasies and subterranean bars?Whatever it was, I was just happy to finally get a seat. The decor is really neat and since there are no windows, it's just one of those watering holes that lets you lose yourself in your drink.The menu had a lot to offer, and they can also do bespoke cocktails as well. I ordered the Czech Connection, and although I can't list all the ingredients in it, just know it was stiff enough and was a nice way to start the weekend.Though you can get bar bites, I love how you can still order off Uma Uma's menu. (This also helps in saving some $$$ as The Horse's Mouth is more high end.) Hooray for getting affordable ramen and rice dishes along with cocktails!We arrived around 7, and even by 8:30 or so the bar wasn't filled up too much. Hopefully this isn't a bad sign, but hey, if you've been meaning to check this place out, perhaps now's the time!

photos.caption: Photo of Horse's Mouth - Singapore, Singapore. Karaage don, $10
Photo of Horse's Mouth - Singapore, Singapore. Garlic ramen from Uma Uma, $17
Photo of Horse's Mouth - Singapore, Singapore. S&R, $24

C5YNnQgibE1xVduwzcxyNQ.text: Love this place! Been here a few times for drinks, and thoroughly enjoyed it and the company. Finally tried the ramen here and it's surprisingly delicious! I tried the truffle ramen and hubby tried the garlic ramen. My brother and friend first introduced me to this place because of the Bloody Mary and the waiter, but I think the waiters have changed since I'm not sure. Anyway, highly recommend for a chill place! Good Japanese whiskey here too, and other cocktails :)

photos.caption: Photo of Horse's Mouth - Singapore, Singapore. Brussels sprouts and gyoza
Photo of Horse's Mouth - Singapore, Singapore. Truffle ramen with flash
Photo of Horse's Mouth - Singapore, Singapore. Garlic ramen

NeAP7WmZ2qlGZxvN8E6zRA.text: Great atmosphere and I'm a sucker for a secret entrance. I had the hadouken sour which was smooth and delicious

exgAKBm1R7XelSGSE3cHDg.text: Drinks are good, 6 out of 10. Service is amateur at the best, maybe childish. It took me one whole hour to get two drinks on a quiet Saturday night.High end prices, low end service.

ixGbM_JmXBolGwMlJtsLAw.text: I was looking for something "different" in the Orchard area and came across this place.  The novelty of the "speakeasy" hidden below a ramen joint added to the fun, and the promise of craft beverages didn't disappoint.  Our bartender was quite social and very knowledgeable about the various spirits he was serving, as well as the history behind the concepts he was using.  Certainly fun talking with him throughout the night.  The cocktails were flavorful and unique.  Be prepared for the expected Singapore pricing, with the cocktails coming it at $25SGD each.To access the bar, you must find the hidden sliding door behind a curtain within the ramen joint.  Then carefully walk down a dark staircase into the basement, which opens up into a sizable bar.  There are tables off to one side of the room, and also plenty of seats around the bar itself.  If you are there for the drinks it is certainly more fun to sit at the bar and interact with the bartenders as they whip up their concoctions.  The room is quite dark, but the ambiance is good.Ordered the tonkatsu ramen from their menu.  It was ok, but nothing mind blowing.  Certainly not cheap at around $20SGD.

KedUgDJ3bWVM5r4b0ltbIg.text: You arrive jetlagged after a 13h flight. Your contact puts you in a taxi that goes straight to Orchard Rd. She drags you down some stairs and through a dimly lit door into a dimly lit bar. You enjoy a steaming bowl of Uma Uma Ramen, your European tongue does not quite understand but it's amazing. Do we really want to try Stingray Fins? Of course we do!The jetlag is gone. Welcome to Singapore. Where do we go next?

QqsVsemiM9hd00ltyoabSg.text: I would suggest just having the ramen and the cocktails. Ramen noodles were al dente with tasty broth. Cocktails were refreshing and balances. Might be able to do with more alcohol Skip the other side dishes even though they might sound tempting on the menu. Quite disappointed with the scallop yuzu dish as was sliced too thickly and was almost chewy.

Vh-bHpdtEDBwUWXZiTDmiA.text: Love the space.Not to impress with my cocktails that night. Perhaps because Louis, the master, was not in. They were mostly too weak and nothing too impressive. But the service was great, the space brilliant, the food yummy. I guess that is good enough for me to want to return.

photos.caption: Photo of Horse's Mouth - Singapore, Singapore. Char siu rice
Photo of Horse's Mouth - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Horse's Mouth - Singapore, Singapore. Kagoshima beef with garlic chips

8xf5cIWV7NQxnM1UmNyxgA.text: This stunning cocktail bar is a hidden gem and well worth writing home about.We shared some fun banter with the friendly guys behind the bar, as well as some great tips on sourcing some local food gems. The cocktails? Some of the best I've had not just in Singapore, but ever. I couldn't tell you exactly what I had, because in each case I ordered off menu and let the boys do their thing after hinting at a few ingredients that float my boat. They nailed it every time. We only spent three nights in Singapore, but came here on two of them!

6NFKm_pO-08DuRr-FxoW-A.text: Friendly guys behind the bar, felt very comfortable with the Japanese minimalist surroundings and atmosphere. These guys are perfectionist and I had a lot of pleasure tasting the product of their labour. They describe them selves not as a speakeasy though in my opinion it comes pretty close.

photos.caption: Photo of Horse's Mouth - Singapore, Singapore

pm_YKe8SDht16i2zBBfVWQ.text: Along with Jigger & Pony, Horse's Mouth is my other major pick for cocktails in Singapore. Bartender Louis is well-versed in the art of the stir & shake and provides pretty great conversation to boot. Pro-tip: ask him why he hates the Moscow Mule cocktail.The usual applies here: a menu exists but one need not be limited by it. Just tell Louis what you feel like drinking and he'll cook something up for you. I recommend their whiskey sour and also suggest you look at their bourbon & rye options. Willett Rye in particular is an excellent choice.You can also get ramen from Uma Uma, which is a pretty solid option for late night grub. The place is small so book ahead on weekends or walk in and sit at the bar on weeknights. My only complaint: early closing time of 12am.

7IzF6LKDlwA8tlGweJIxhg.text: Sat down for a drink and snacks with two colleagues.  The setting was nice, cool, and quiet enough to talk so that was a plus.  Food (pan fried dumplings and some chicken strips, and some ramen) was not special and overpriced.  There was no drink menu but the girl taking our orders was reasonably helpful.  My one colleague did say her sweet whiskey based drink was excellent but the others were just so-so ....This was not what we were looking for but if you are looking for hit and miss $30 drinks then definitely check it out.

kRsOEYpMITu-1DLB8OCHww.text: Ok - I'm not that much of a drinker or going to bars every weekend. I do enjoy a drink or two every once in a while with good friends. I was looking for a place to go after teaching my dance class with my friends for my birthday drinks and found this place searching through Yelp. (Thanks Yelp!)We took a while to find the entrance for this place - we went through a dark door through Uma Uma Ramen even though the restaurant was closed the door was surprisingly still open and we found our way downstairs to Horse's Mouth. What a pleasant and beautiful surprise! The place is impeccably designed. Very Classy. My small group was seated immediately and we ordered amazing specialty cocktails. For once in my life, I was able to order a Cosmopolitan (I'm allergic to Cranberries) because they make it with Pomegranate juice. It was delicious! My second drink was also delicious and I told the bartender, Louis that I wanted something fruity, fizzy, and with rum in it. The drinks here are strong but also go down easy. Drinks in Singapore ain't cheap, and too many bars serve them watered down. This bar doesn't serve their drinks watered down and the concoctions are original. Very nice bartender as well. He kept coming over and talking to us. Great place to bring a group of friends for some drinks and conversation. :-) Definitely had a fun night. I will be coming back here.

cZujPkO2YQF1k97Kh-GcHw.text: Brand spanking new, and sleek as hell.A friend asked me to go check out this mysterious place with him - turns out to be under a new ramen joint, and ultra posh too.Apparently it was opening night, and despite rocking up fashionable late (we had to get grub at a wallet-friendly location first), it was standing room only for us.No matter though, this meant we got to chat with the bartender (Louis, who is awesome).He's what they call a mixologist - he'll make you something based on what you tell him: how you feel, what you had for lunch, and maybe even your horoscope... no promises on that last one though.A couple drinks later, my memory gets a little hazy, but I remember them drinks going down easy, and that to me is the mark of a solid cocktail. Japanese bar snacks aren't bad either; we had some of the tastiest saukura ebi I can remember.When I get a chance to go back, I'll make sure to ask all my burning questions: why is the bar called Horse's Mouth, and why is Louis so damn awesome!?Till then, let me recover from this crazy headache that I woke up with...
